awd_titl_txt: XPS: EXPL: FP: Collaborative Research: SPANDAN: Scalable Parallel Algorithms for Network Dynamics Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of SPANDAN project is to create a novel architecture-independent framework 
for designing efficient, portable and scalable parallel algorithms for analyzing 
large-scale dynamic networks. SPANDAN will not only provide an intuitive methodology 
for efficiently translating sequential algorithms into scalable parallel algorithms 
for dynamic networks, but also provide mechanisms for their analytical evaluation and 
serve as a mediatory layer between applications and system level tuning. To evaluate 
the effectiveness of SPANDAN framework in real-world applications, the PIs will 
collaborate with social scientists and biologists. They will also integrate research 
findings into various courses such as network analysis, parallel algorithms, and 
bioinformatics. They will further collaborate with high schools to develop summer courses 
with the goal of encouraging women and minority students to pursue IT-related careers. 


As the underlying methodology, the SPANDAN framework will exploit graph sparsification 
techniques to divide the network into sparse subgraphs (certificates) that form the 
leaves of a sparsification tree. This innovative approach will lead to the design and 
analysis of efficient parallel algorithms for updating dynamic networks, and reduction 
of memory latency associated with parallelizing unstructured data. Specifically parallel 
algorithms will be designed for maintaining network topological characteristics, and 
updating influential vertices and communities. To demonstrate portability and performance, 
the developed algorithms will be implemented on the distributed memory clusters, shared 
memory multicores, and massively multithreaded CRAY-XMT.

For further information see the project web site at:
 http://cs.mst.edu/labs/crewman/projects/SPANDAN/

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits. Analysis of dynamic networks is an important research problem that having applications in many disciplines from epidemiology to biology to social sciences. Through the SPANDAN project we developed the foundations of creating a template for updating properties of dynamic networks in parallel. Specifically, we observed that for each property, there are some key edges and only changes to the set of key edges will update the property. Based on this observation, we developed a template for designing scalable parallel algorithms to update tree-like properties, such as connected components, minimum weighted spanning trees, and single source shortest paths.

 

Another important aspect to consider when studying dynamic networks is to identify whether the change in the network properties occurred due to actual evolution of the network, or due to noise in the system. We modeled noise by perturbing (adding or deleting) a small percentage of edges. We observed that the core periphery property of the network is important in determining its stability.

 

The publications related to these discoveries, along with associated codes, will facilitate domain scientists to analyze evolving networks faster and more accurately. Our template will also enable network science researchers to develop parallel algorithms for updating various properties of dynamic networks.

 

Broader Impacts. The results of the SPANDAN project were disseminated via presentations and publications at international conferences and journals. The project partially supported the research of 3 Ph.D.  students, 4 Masters students and 3 undergraduates. Results from the project were incorporated into courses in parallel computing, graph theory, and network analysis at the PIs’ universities.  We also organized mini-symposia at the SIAM Annual Meeting (2016) and IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM 2017) on the effect of noise in networks. We have also collaborated with researchers in bioinformatics, biochemical problems, cyber-physical systems, and epidemiology to apply our algorithms to their domains.
